prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: For guidance in planning sensitivity limits, we use CO(1-0) fluxes measured for similar circumnuclear disks in nearby early-type galaxies based on CARMA observations from Alatalo et al. (2013). Targets in that sample having disks whose characteristics are similar to the disks in our sample include NGC 3665, NGC 4429, and NGC 4435. Of these, NGC 4435 is the faintest target with a total CO(1-0) line flux of 32 Jy km/s and a line width of 400 km/s. The intensity ratio CO(2-1)/CO(1-0) in NGC 4435 is 1.3 (Young et al. 2011). The distance to NGC 4435 is 16.7 Mpc. Our sensitivity calculations are based on scaling the observed CO(2-1) flux of NGC 4435 to the distances of the targets in our sample.
Our sensitivity requirements are set by the following considerations:
1. If the target has a CO(2-1) luminosity identical to that of NGC 4435, then our minimum goal is to measure the integrated line profile shape to high accuracy, with S/N=20 per velocity channel using 20 km/s channel widths. This will allow for accurate modeling of the spatially integrated line profile to constrain M_BH. If the S/N significantly exceeds this threshold then we will be able to carry out spatially-resolved dynamical model fits to fully determine M_BH.
2. Even if the target has an intrinsic CO(2-1) luminosity 10x lower than that of NGC 4435, we aim to achieve a high-significance integrated detection of the line (at least a 10sigma detection). We assume a velocity width of 400 km/s for the line.
3. In order to make efficient use of ALMA and avoid an overhead-dominated program, we also set a requirement that overheads should not constitute more than 30% of the total time request for any target. Since total overheads are typically 16 minutes per target according to the OT Time Estimate, this requirement sets a minimum on-source exposure time of ~20 minutes. This corresponds to achieving a sensitivity of 0.6 mJy for a 20 km/s channel width.
For IC 4296 (our most distant target at D=49 Mpc), requirement #1 sets a limiting sensitivity of 0.6 mJy to achieve S/N=20 in a 20 km/s velocity channel if the target's CO luminosity is identical to that of NGC 4435. This corresponds to an on-source exposure time of 22.7 min. Requirement #2 for detection of the line even if it has 10x lower luminosity than NGC 4435 sets a sensitivity requirement of 0.12 mJy over a 400 km/s velocity channel, which corresponds to a slightly longer on-source exposure time of 28.4 min. We use this latter requirement to set our exposure request for this source. Including overheads and calibration, the total request for IC 4296 is 1.09 h.
We note that a preliminary announcement of a CO detection for IC 4296 was recently given in a conference proceeding by Prandoni et al. (2012), but the APEX single-dish observation has angular resolution of 30" FWHM, and does not give direct information on the line flux from the inner arcsec.
Imaging: We request an angular resolution of 0.35" since this will resolve the BH sphere of influence of these targets and permits the direct detection of high-velocity emission from rapid rotation within r_g. This also provides sensitivity to structures up to 6" in extent which is well matched to the disk sizes. Pushing to even higher angular resolutions would not yet be justified given the unknown CO fluxes on small scales in these targets.
Correlator Setup: Our primary goal is to observe 12CO(2-1) at rest frequency 230.5 GHz. We place one baseband centered on this redshifted line, and another baseband on an adjacent continuum region. In order to keep the data rate low we request only two basebands.
Calibration: We will use system-defined default calibrations.
Bandpass accuracy: No special requirements.
Scheduling constraints: None.
Data rate: Since we are only requesting two basebands we do not incur a high data rate. (Selection of additional basebands would increase the data rate to >12 MB/s.)
Special constraints: None.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: ALMA will make it possible to measure masses of supermassive black holes in early-type galaxies via an entirely new method, by mapping the kinematics of rotating, circumnuclear molecular disks. HST images provide an optimal method for pre-selection of targets, because ~10% of early-type galaxies have circumnuclear dust disks on arcsecond scales which are associated with regular rotational kinematics. However, there are very few southern-hemisphere early-type galaxies that have round, symmetric dust disks and known CO fluxes. We propose 12CO(2-1) observations of the six best and most promising southern-hemisphere targets culled from an extensive search of the HST archives. Our efficient observations will resolve the gravitational sphere of influence of the black holes and reveal rapid rotation from molecular gas in the inner disks, and we will carry out dynamical modeling to derive constraints on the black hole masses. Once we have determined the CO fluxes and linewidths, in future ALMA cycles we will propose to carry out deeper and higher-resolution observations that will provide exquisitely accurate black hole masses.
